Award.AwardTitle: California WaterWorks: Building the People Pipeline

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The California WaterWorks: Building the People Pipeline is a project at Cuyamaca College to identify and train the next generation of water industry professionals who will operate and maintain the critical infrastructure that keeps our water safe and reliable. The project will develop a new "Institute for Water Studies" that embeds contextualized STEM learning opportunities in technical courses at the college. It will also work with local 7-12 math and science teachers to provide contextualized teaching modules and demonstrations of water and wastewater equipment for 7-12 students. Students at the college will assemble an above-ground water distribution system that allows them to hone their mechanical skills and gain relevant job experience in the classroom. Through these activities, the project will develop career pathways that recruit women, underrepresented students, and veterans into careers in water and wastewater management.

As part of their effort to educate the next generation of water technicians and replace an aging workforce, the California WaterWorks project will develop new stackable certifications in water treatment, water distribution, wastewater treatment, and wastewater collection. These certificates will offer multiple entrance, multiple exit pathways aligned with industry standards and credentials. The project will also implement the ACT WorkKeys and National Career Readiness Certification materials to improve students' job readiness and soft skills. To support recruitment efforts, the project will work with ATETV to produce a series of recruitment video that target women and transitioning military personnel with STEM skills, and inform them of career opportunities in the water and wastewater management industries. The curricula, videos, and other teaching materials will be shared with other community colleges through the ATE network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cuyamaca College received an NSF ATE grant (2016-19; award # 1601775-extended to 2020) to implement California WaterWorks: Building the People Pipeline for its Center for Water Studies. This project supported the creation of an above-ground Field Operations Skills Yard (FOSY) which includes a water distribution system, a fully equipped water quality laboratory, and a state-of-the-art shop for backflow and cross connection control training. The FOSY, in an approximately 70' x 70' area, consists of two 2,000-gallon storage tanks, two pumping stations, approximately 268' of 6' and 8' piping, 21 valves of various sizes and types, and related instrumentation, control, and monitoring systems.  Students are able to gain hands-on experience using the tools and equipment at an above ground water distribution system, a wastewater collection system, and a full array of pumps, valves, pipes, fittings, meters and gauges. 

California WaterWorks: Building the People Pipeline also allowed for the creation of stackable educational pathways leading to industry certifications in water treatment, water distribution, wastewater treatment, and wastewater collections.  The entire existing curriculum had been modified to incorporate industry standards under the advisement of the Industry Advisory Committee in addressing the need for high priority workplace skills. This project allowed for the creation of two new courses, Career Pathways in the Water and Wastewater Industry and Introduction to Water and Wastewater Industry Health and Safety issues.  

In addition, California WaterWorks: Building the People Pipeline focused on increased engagement of veterans and women in career pathways, and conducted outreach and educational activities to local high schools. In support of this engagement, this project allowed for maintained industry connections and active participation on a number of industry committees, including San Diego County Water Authority's Regional Workforce Development Work Group and America WaterWorks Association's Veteran Engagement and Transition Committee. Cuyamaca College hosted three Women in Water Symposiums providing professional development and networking opportunities to high school and college students, early career professionals and seasoned professionals. Cuyamaca College produced a number of videos to highlight industry professionals and career opportunities at water agencies in San Diego County and remains a crucial partner in advancing the water industry.
